abstract.text: Polyadenylation of mRNA in human mitochondria is crucial for gene expression and perturbation of poly(A) tail length has been linked to a human neurodegenerative disease.

Here we show that 2 0-phosphodiesterase (2 0-PDE), (hereafter PDE12), is a mitochondrial protein that specifically removes poly(A) extensions from mitochondrial mRNAs both in vitro and in mitochondria of cultured cells.
In eukaryotes, poly(A) tails generally stabilize mature mRNAs, whereas in bacteria they increase mRNA turnover.
In human mitochondria, the effects of increased PDE12 expression were transcript dependent.

An excess of PDE12 led to an increase in the level of three mt-mRNAs (ND1, ND2 and CytB) and two (CO1 and CO2) were less abundant than in mitochondria of control cells and there was no appreciable effect on the steady-state level of the remainder of the mitochondrial transcripts.
The alterations in poly(A) tail length accompanying elevated PDE12 expression were associated with severe inhibition of mitochondrial protein synthesis, and consequently respiratory incompetence.
Therefore, we propose that mRNA poly(A) tails are important in regulating protein synthesis in human mitochondria, as it is the case for nuclear-encoded eukaryotic mRNA.

body_text.text: INTRODUCTION
Mitochondria are vital organelles as they provide energy to the cell via the process of oxidative phosphorylation (OXPHOS).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The 16.6 kb circular human mitochondrial genome (mtDNA) encodes 2 rRNAs, 22 tRNAs and 13 essential protein components of the OXPHOS complexes (1).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The remaining proteins of the mitochondrial proteome (>99%), including all factors necessary for the maintenance and expression of mtDNA, are encoded by the nucleus.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Both mtDNA strands (termed H and L) are almost entirely transcribed from the promoters located in the control non-coding region.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Resulting polycistronic RNA molecules are then processed to produce mRNAs, rRNAs and tRNAs (2).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Human mitochondrial mRNAs (mt-mRNAs) released by this processing do not contain introns and lack any cap or modification at the 5 0 -end; however, they do have $50 adenosine residues added at the 3 0 -terminus by a dedicated mitochondrial poly(A) polymerase (3,4).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Seven of the 13 open reading frames (ORFs) require polyadenylation to create a translation stop codon (5).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Regulation of human mitochondrial RNA (mt-RNA) surveillance and turnover has not been well characterized thus far (6,7); also the regulatory mechanisms that control mitochondrial translation are poorly understood (8).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: In many systems, RNA polyadenylation plays an important role both in controlling mRNA stability and in modulating translation (9).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The human mitochondrial poly(A) polymerase (hmtPAP) responsible for the synthesis of the mitochondrial poly(A) extensions has been identified (3,4), however, inactivation of this enzyme did not yield a clear answer to the role of poly(A) extensions in the stability of mt-RNAs.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The siRNA-mediated knockdown of hmtPAP led to shortening of mitochondrial 3 0 -poly(A) extensions, but this either did not affect the stability (3) or resulted in decreased steady-state levels of some mt-mRNAs (4,10).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Furthermore, analysis of the ATP6/8 mt-mRNA (RNA14) harbouring a microdeletion in the translation stop codon in a patient-derived cell line showed that this message has shortened poly(A) tails and is less stable, consistent with the poly(A) tail stabilizing the ATP6/8 mRNA (11).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Another approach based upon mitochondrial targeting of a poly(A)-specific 3 0exoribonuclease PARN led to efficient RNA deadenylation; however, this had a variable effect on mt-mRNA steady-state levels, increasing or decreasing particular mRNAs with no effect on others (12).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Another previous study showed that a fraction of the mt-RNA is truncated and internally polyadenylated, consistent with the possibility that a poly(A)-dependent degradation pathway exists in human mitochondria (13).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Also, oligoadenylation at the 3 0 -termini has been suggested to precede the addition of long poly(A) tails, (14,15), but to date no enzyme responsible for the synthesis of oligo(A) extensions has been identified.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: By analogy with the role of RNA polyadenylation in the cytosol of eukaryotes, poly(A) tails may also play a role in modulating mitochondrial translation.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: However, this potential function has received very little attention thus far (12).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Deadenylase enzymes ensure changes of the lengths of mRNA poly(A) in order to regulate mRNA stability and therefore protein production.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: All known human deadenylases belong to two enzyme families classified on the basis of conserved nuclease motifs (16):
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: (i) the DEDD family, e.g. POP2, PARN and PAN2 deadenylases and
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: (ii) the ribonucleases of the exonuclease/endonuclease/phosphatase (EEP) family, e.g. CCR4 (CNOT6), Nocturnin and ANGEL (16).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: All human deadenylases characterized thus far have been localized either to the cytosol or the nucleus (or found to shuttle between these two compartments).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Therefore, the mechanism of regulation of mRNA poly(A) tail length in mitochondria was not known.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: We studied PDE12 because it shares sequence homology with known RNA deadenylases and in silico analysis predicted its a mitochondrial localization.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: PDE12 is an exoribonuclease with a preference for homo-adenine oligonucleotides, and removes poly(A) tail extensions from mt-mRNAs in vitro and in mitochondria of cells in culture.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Deadenylation altered the steady-state level of some, but not other, mitochondrial mRNAs, which may explain earlier contradictory results of the effect of mitochondrial poly(A) tails on controlling mt-mRNA stability.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: We also show that deadenylation of mt-mRNA led to a marked inhibition of mitochondrial protein synthesis, suggesting that poly(A) tails modulate translation in mitochondria.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: MATERIALS AND METHODS
Plasmids

In order to construct the pcDNA5-PDE12.Strep2.Flag plasmid used to generate an inducible Flp-In T-Rex TM human embryonic kidney 293 T (HEK293T) cell line, two oligonucleotides encoding an AgeI restriction site, Flag and Strep2 epitope tags were annealed and cloned into XbaI (5 0 ) and ApaI (3 0 ) restriction sites of pcDNA5/ FRT/TO (Invitrogen).
body_text.section: Plasmids

body_text.text: The resulting plasmid was named pcDNA5-FST2.
body_text.section: Plasmids

body_text.text: The cDNA-encoding PDE12 (IMAGE clone: 4823249) was then modified by PCR to introduce unique KpnI (5 0 ) and AgeI (3 0 ) sites and the resulting fragment was cloned into pcDNA5-FST2 using the above restriction sites.
body_text.section: Plasmids

body_text.text: The E351A catalytic mutant was generated using PCR-based mutagenesis and the resulting cDNA was cloned into pcDNA5-FST2 as above.
body_text.section: Plasmids

body_text.text: For transfection of mammalian cells plasmid, DNA was purified using a Qiafilter MidiPrep Kit (Qiagen).

body_text.text: Maintenance, transfection and growth analysis of mammalian cell lines

Human 143B osteosarcoma (HOS) cells that are routinely used by us for immunofluorescence localization of mitochondrial proteins were cultured in Dulbecco's Modified Eagle Medium (DMEM) containing 2 mM L-glutamine (Invitrogen) with 10% FBS (PAA Laboratories).

body_text.text: For immunofluorescence experiments, HOS cells were electroporated with pcDNA5-PDE12.Strep2.Flag using Cell Line Nucleofector (Lonza) and buffer kit V (Lonza) applying programme I-13.
body_text.section: Maintenance, transfection and growth analysis of mammalian cell lines

body_text.text: The Flp-In T-Rex TM HEK293T cell line (Invitrogen), which allows for the generation of stable, doxycyclineinducible expression of transgenes by FLP recombinasemediated integration was used to express PDE12 .
body_text.section: Maintenance, transfection and growth analysis of mammalian cell lines

body_text.text: Strep2.Flag and the E351A catalytic mutant.
body_text.section: Maintenance, transfection and growth analysis of mammalian cell lines

body_text.text: HEK293T cells were grown in DMEM containing 2 mM L-glutamine (Invitrogen), 10% tetracycline free FCS (Autogen Bioclear) and supplemented with 100 mg/ml Zeocin (Invivogen) and 15 mg/ml Blasticidin (Invivogen).
body_text.section: Maintenance, transfection and growth analysis of mammalian cell lines

body_text.text: Twenty-four hours prior to transfection cells were split to 10 cm plates, grown to 80-90% confluence and transfected using Cell Line Nucleofector (Lonza), buffer kit V (Lonza) applying programme A-23.
body_text.section: Maintenance, transfection and growth analysis of mammalian cell lines

body_text.text: Twenty-four hours after transfection, the selective antibiotics hygromycin (100 mg/ml, Invivogen) and blasticidin (15 mg/ml) were added and the selective medium was replaced every 3-4 days.
body_text.section: Maintenance, transfection and growth analysis of mammalian cell lines

body_text.text: For growth on respiratory substrates, the medium contained glucose-free DMEM (Gibco), 0.9 mg/ml galactose, 1 mM sodium pyruvate, 10% (v/v) FCS and 2 mM L-glutamine.
body_text.section: Maintenance, transfection and growth analysis of mammalian cell lines

body_text.text: For growth measurements cells were plated in six-well plates and grown with 50 ng/ml of doxycycline in galactose or glucose containing medium.
body_text.section: Maintenance, transfection and growth analysis of mammalian cell lines

body_text.text: Immunodetection of proteins
The immunofluorescence localization of proteins in fixed HOS cells were performed as described previously (17).
body_text.section: Immunodetection of proteins

body_text.text: The following antibodies were used: anti-Flag IgG (Sigma, 1:200), FITC-conjugated anti-mouse IgG (Sigma, 1:200).
body_text.section: Immunodetection of proteins

body_text.text: Immunofluorescence images were captured using a Zeiss LSM 510 META confocal microscope.
body_text.section: Immunodetection of proteins

body_text.text: For immunoblot analysis, equal amounts of proteins corresponding to total cell lysates or protein fractions were subjected to SDS-PAGE, semi-dry transferred to nitrocellulose membranes, blocked in 5% non-fat milk (Marvel) in PBS for 1 h and incubated with specific primary antibodies in 5% non-fat milk in PBS for 1 h or overnight.
body_text.section: Immunodetection of proteins

body_text.text: The blots were further incubated with HRP-conjugated secondary antibodies in 5% non-fat milk in PBS for 1 h and visualized using ECL + (Amersham).
body_text.section: Immunodetection of proteins

body_text.text: The primary antibodies used were: rabbit anti-PDE12 (Abcam, 1:1000), mouse anti-FLAG IgG (Sigma, 1:5000), rabbit anti-b-actin IgG (1:7000, Sigma), mouse anti-CO2 IgG (1:5000, Abcam), rabbit anti-TFAM IgG (kindly donated by Professor Rudolf Wiesner, University of Cologne, 1:4000), mouse anti-GAPDH IgG (Abcam, 1:10 000), mouse anti-Complex I subunit NDUFB8 (MitoSciences, 1:2000), mouse anti-Complex II subunit 30 kDa (MitoSciences, 1:2000), mouse anti-Complex III subunit Core 2 (MitoSciences, 1:2000), rabbit anti-VDAC-1 IgG (Abcam, 1:5000), mouse anti-DAP3 IgG (Abcam, 1:1000) and goat anti-MRPL3 (Abcam, 1:1000).
body_text.section: Immunodetection of proteins

body_text.text: Protein purification

Mitochondria derived from HEK293T cells expressing PDE12.Strep2.Flag or the E351A catalytic mutant were isolated as described previously (18) and resuspended to 8 mg protein/ml in 40 mM HEPES (pH 7.6), 10 mM EDTA, 4 mM DTT, 0.4 mM PMSF, 300 mM NaCl and protease inhibitor cocktail (Roche).
body_text.section: Protein purification

body_text.text: Next, the mitochondria were lysed by mixing with an equal volume of 0.8% dodecylmaltoside (DDM) in water, on a roller at 4 C for 30 min.
body_text.section: Protein purification

body_text.text: The lysate was centrifuged at 1600 g max for 10 min to remove insoluble debris and the supernatant was loaded onto a gravity flow Strep-Tactin column (IBA) and the flow-through re-loaded twice.
body_text.section: Protein purification

body_text.text: The column was washed sequentially with five column volumes (CV) of washing buffer containing 20 mM HEPES (pH 7.6), 1 mM EDTA, 2 mM DTT, 0.2 mM PMSF, 150 mM NaCl, 0.05% DDM, protease inhibitors (Roche) and eluted six times with 0.5 CV elution buffer (washing buffer plus 10 mM desthiobiotin).
body_text.section: Protein purification

body_text.text: Peak fractions containing PDE12.Strep2.Flag were concentrated using Vivaspin 2 Centrifugal Concentrators (Sartorius stedim), supplemented with glycerol to 20% and stored at À80 C. In order to assess the purity and identity of the Strep-Tactin purified proteins, the preparations were separated by SDS-PAGE, Coomassie stained and protein bands were excised from gels and identified by mass spectrometry.
body_text.section: Protein purification

body_text.text: The reaction mixture of 20 ml containing 5 pmoles of the substrate, 50 mM HEPES (pH 8.0), 10 mM MgCl 2 , 0.5 mM DTT, 100 mg/ml BSA, 4 U of RNasin (Promega) and 8.5 pmols of PDE12 or E351A catalytic mutant were incubated at 37 C for the indicated time.

body_text.text: Analysis of mitochondrial poly(A) by circular reverse transcription-PCR assay

body_text.section: Analysis of mitochondrial poly(A) by circular reverse transcription-PCR assay

body_text.section: Analysis of mitochondrial poly(A) by circular reverse transcription-PCR assay

body_text.section: Analysis of mitochondrial poly(A) by circular reverse transcription-PCR assay

body_text.text: The region amplified contained the junction of the 5 0and 3 0 -extremities.
body_text.section: Analysis of mitochondrial poly(A) by circular reverse transcription-PCR assay

body_text.text: A second round of PCR with the nested reverse primer, R2, and forward primer, F2, was applied.
body_text.section: Analysis of mitochondrial poly(A) by circular reverse transcription-PCR assay

35 S-methionine metabolic labelling of mitochondrial proteins
Stably transfected HEK293T cells expressing PDE12 (or E351A) were induced with doxycycline (50 ng/ml) for 2 or 4 days prior to 35 S labelling.
body_text.section: S-methionine metabolic labelling of mitochondrial proteins

body_text.text: Growth medium was replaced with methionine/cysteine-free DMEM (Sigma) supplemented with 2 mM L-glutamine, 48 mg/ml cysteine and 50 mg/ml uridine.
body_text.section: S-methionine metabolic labelling of mitochondrial proteins

body_text.text: The cells were incubated for 2 Â 10 min in this medium and then transfered into fresh methionine/ cysteine-free DMEM medium containing 10% (v/v) dialysed FCS and emetine dihydrochloride (100 mg/ml).
body_text.section: S-methionine metabolic labelling of mitochondrial proteins

body_text.text: Cells were incubated for 10 min before addition of 120 mCi/ml of [ 35 S]-methionine.
body_text.section: S-methionine metabolic labelling of mitochondrial proteins

body_text.text: RESULTS
In silico characterization and mitochondrial localization of PDE12
The previously identified 2 0 -PDE protein (19), hereafter PDE12, contains the domain characteristics of the endonuclease/exonuclease/phosphatase (EEP) family of proteins (PFAM: PF03372).
body_text.section: In silico characterization and mitochondrial localization of PDE12

body_text.text: In order to examine the genetic divergence of human PDE12 and other human proteins with the PF03372 domain we built a classification tree ( Figure 1A).
body_text.section: In silico characterization and mitochondrial localization of PDE12

body_text.text: The analysis revealed that human PDE12 belongs to a subgroup that contains all established and putative human deadenylases from the EEP family ( Figure 1A, red) as described by Goldstrohm and Wickens (16).
body_text.section: In silico characterization and mitochondrial localization of PDE12

body_text.text: Human PDE12 shares the same general domain architecture ( Figure 1B) and all key catalytic residues with other EEP deadenylases (Supplementary Figure S1).
body_text.section: In silico characterization and mitochondrial localization of PDE12

body_text.text: Furthermore, 3D homology modelling of the PDE12 active site based on the crystal structure of the poly(A)-specific ribonuclease CNOT6L (20) indicated a similar arrangement of the key catalytic residues ( Figure  1C and D).
body_text.section: In silico characterization and mitochondrial localization of PDE12

body_text.text: Several computer programmes that scan the N-terminal region of proteins for the presence of a putative mitochondrial targeting sequence (MTS) returned a high probability of a MTS in PDE12 (MultiLoc -98.0%, MitoProt II -94%, Predotar -81%, TargetP -77% and PSORT -75%).
body_text.section: In silico characterization and mitochondrial localization of PDE12

body_text.text: Moreover, PDE12 is listed in the compendium of predicted mitochondrial proteins ['Mitocarta', (21)] constructed on the basis of subtractive proteomics of mitochondria from different tissues, mRNA co-expression, transcriptional induction during mitochondrial proliferation, homology studies and more.
body_text.section: In silico characterization and mitochondrial localization of PDE12

body_text.text: Therefore, PDE12 represented a strong candidate for a mitochondrial poly(A)-specific ribonuclease.
body_text.section: In silico characterization and mitochondrial localization of PDE12

body_text.text: Indeed, while our manuscript was in preparation, Poulsen et al. (22) reported that a His-tagged version of PDE12 (2 0 -PDE) is localized in the mitochondrial matrix of HeLa cells (as shown by immunofluorescence, in vitro import of 35 S-labelled recombinant protein and mass spectrometry of mitochondrial fractions).
body_text.section: In silico characterization and mitochondrial localization of PDE12

body_text.text: Transiently expressed PDE12 with Flag and Strep2 tags also co-localizes with mitochondria, in HOS cells (Figure 2A), and endogenous PDE12 co-fractionates with the well-characterized mitochondrial matrix protein TFAM and the mitochondrial inner membrane CO2 ( Figure 2B).
body_text.section: In silico characterization and mitochondrial localization of PDE12

body_text.text: Therefore, it is now established by two laboratories, using four different techniques, that the PDE12 protein is present inside the mitochondria of human cells.
body_text.section: In silico characterization and mitochondrial localization of PDE12

body_text.text: PDE12 has deadenylase activity in vitro
Since PDE12 contains a domain similar to deadenylases (Figure 1), we tested PDE12 for sequence-specific nuclease activity.
body_text.section: PDE12 has deadenylase activity in vitro

body_text.text: We generated a point mutation in a putative magnesium-binding residue by substituting glutamate at position 351 with alanine (E351A, Figure 1C, cyan).
body_text.section: PDE12 has deadenylase activity in vitro

body_text.text: A point mutation in the analogous residue severely compromised the activity of other EEP deadenylases (20,23).
body_text.section: PDE12 has deadenylase activity in vitro

body_text.text: In order to purify the enzymes for biochemical studies, a Flag-and Strep2-tagged version of the PDE12 wild-type and the E351A mutant were introduced into HEK293T cells.
body_text.section: PDE12 has deadenylase activity in vitro

body_text.text: The mitochondrial localization of the overexpressed wild-type PDE12 and the E351A mutant in HEK293T cells was confirmed by fractionation after induction of the transgenes for 48 h with 50 ng/ml of doxycycline.
body_text.section: PDE12 has deadenylase activity in vitro

body_text.text: Both proteins were concentrated in the mitochondrial fraction (Supplementary Figure S2A).
body_text.section: PDE12 has deadenylase activity in vitro

body_text.text: The enzymes were purified from mitochondria of HEK293T cells on a streptavidin-coated matrix (see 'Material and Methods' section).
body_text.section: PDE12 has deadenylase activity in vitro

body_text.text: SDS-PAGE analysis demonstrated a substantial enrichment of the tagged proteins (Supplementary Figure  S2B) and their identities were confirmed by mass spectrometry (data not shown).
body_text.section: PDE12 has deadenylase activity in vitro

body_text.text: First, we compared the hydrolytic activity of PDE12 and the E351A mutant using 25 nt-long, homopolymeric RNA (A 25 ) or DNA (dA 25 ) substrates, labelled at their 5 0 -ends.
body_text.section: PDE12 has deadenylase activity in vitro

body_text.text: We observed a time-dependent degradation of the RNA with wild-type, but not E351A mutant, PDE12; neither protein had any effect on DNA ( Figure  3A).
body_text.section: PDE12 has deadenylase activity in vitro

body_text.text: The degradation of the 5 0 -end-labelled A 25 substrate resulted in a progressive and sequential appearance of RNA fragments of lower molecular mass suggesting that the enzyme hydrolyses RNA in the 3 0 !
body_text.section: PDE12 has deadenylase activity in vitro

body_text.text: 5 0 direction.
body_text.section: PDE12 has deadenylase activity in vitro

body_text.text: The addition of a phosphate group at the 3 0 -end of RNA (substrate A 25 pCp) completely inhibited RNA degradation, whereas the analogous RNA substrate with a 3 0 -hydroxyl group (A 25 pC-OH) was efficiently degraded by the wild-type enzyme ( Figure 3A).
body_text.section: PDE12 has deadenylase activity in vitro

body_text.text: These results suggest that PDE12 displays specificity for RNA 3 0 -ends containing a free hydroxyl group, and does not possess 5 0 !
body_text.section: PDE12 has deadenylase activity in vitro

body_text.text: 3 0 exoribonucleolytic or endoribonucleolytic activity.
body_text.section: PDE12 has deadenylase activity in vitro

body_text.text: Next, we studied the specificity of PDE12 by comparing the time-dependent hydrolytic activity of PDE12 on 25 nt-long homopolymeric RNA substrates i.e. A 25 , C 25 , G 25 or U 25 ( Figure 3B).
body_text.section: PDE12 has deadenylase activity in vitro

body_text.text: PDE12 preferred A 25 and U 25 as substrates, whereas C 25 and in particular G 25 were poorly degraded.
body_text.section: PDE12 has deadenylase activity in vitro

body_text.text: The specificity of PDE12 towards poly(A) tails was further characterized on RNA substrates containing:
body_text.section: PDE12 has deadenylase activity in vitro

body_text.text: (i) a 111 nt-long 3 0 -portion of the ND1 human mitochondrial gene (3 0 ND1) or
body_text.section: PDE12 has deadenylase activity in vitro

body_text.text: (ii) the same 3 0 -portion of ND1 containing a 50 nt poly(A) tail (3 0 ND1-A 50 ).
body_text.section: PDE12 has deadenylase activity in vitro

body_text.text: Analogous substrates containing a 111 nt-long 3 0 -portion of the CO2 human mitochondrial gene (3 0 CO2 and 3 0 CO2-A 50 , respectively) were also tested.
body_text.section: PDE12 has deadenylase activity in vitro

body_text.text: Incubation of recombinant PDE12, but not the E351A mutant, with the polyadenylated substrates (3 0 ND1-A 50 or 3 0 CO2-A 50 ) for 30 min resulted in a size change consistent with the removal of the poly(A) tail ( Figure 3C, compare lanes 4 and 5 or 10 and 11).
body_text.section: PDE12 has deadenylase activity in vitro

body_text.text: Of note, the enzyme trimmed both substrates $6-8 nt beyond the poly(A) tail into the body of the message ( Figure 3C indicate that PDE12 can operate as an RNase with specificity for poly(A) tails.
body_text.section: PDE12 has deadenylase activity in vitro

body_text.text: PDE12 transgene expression alters the length of RNA poly(A) tails in mitochondria
Based on the in vitro data (Figure 3), a high dose of PDE12 in mitochondria is predicted to shorten poly(A) tails.
body_text.section: PDE12 transgene expression alters the length of RNA poly(A) tails in mitochondria

body_text.text: In order to determine the effect of PDE12 on RNA poly(A) tail length of mitochondrial transcripts, recombinant PDE12 or the E351A catalytic mutant was expressed in HEK293T cells.
body_text.section: PDE12 transgene expression alters the length of RNA poly(A) tails in mitochondria

body_text.text: Both proteins were equally stable in human mitochondria ( Figure 4A).
body_text.section: PDE12 transgene expression alters the length of RNA poly(A) tails in mitochondria

body_text.text: In order to map the exact changes in mt-RNA species, total RNA was isolated parental HEK293T cells.
body_text.section: PDE12 transgene expression alters the length of RNA poly(A) tails in mitochondria

body_text.text: The length and sequence of mitochondrial transcripts ND1 and CO2 were analysed after PCR amplification, circularization, reverse transcription and cloning (cRT-PCR).
body_text.section: PDE12 transgene expression alters the length of RNA poly(A) tails in mitochondria

body_text.text: All mitochondrial transcripts analyzed preserved the normal 5 0 -end, but in approximately half of the CO2 transcripts the length of the poly(A) tail was reduced to 40 adenines or less (48 and 54% for 2 and 4 days of PDE12 overexpression, respectively); all of the ND1 transcripts had poly(A) tails shorter than 40 adenines after 2 or 4 days of PDE12 overexpression ( Figure 4B and Supplementary Table S2).
body_text.section: PDE12 transgene expression alters the length of RNA poly(A) tails in mitochondria

body_text.text: In $8 and 41% of the CO2 and ND1 transcripts, respectively, the poly(A) tail was lost completely 4 days after PDE12 induction.
body_text.section: PDE12 transgene expression alters the length of RNA poly(A) tails in mitochondria

body_text.text: Similarly to the data obtained in vitro ( Figure 3C), RNA truncation of the ND1 and CO2 transcripts by PDE12 did not stop at the beginning of the poly(A) tract, but continued for up to 8 nt, into the 3 0 -termini of the transcripts (Supplementary Table S2).
body_text.section: PDE12 transgene expression alters the length of RNA poly(A) tails in mitochondria

body_text.text: Some of the truncated ND1 transcripts were re-adenylated ( Supplementary Table S2).
body_text.section: PDE12 transgene expression alters the length of RNA poly(A) tails in mitochondria

body_text.text: Mitochondrial transcripts of cells overexpressing the E351A catalytic mutant were indistinguishable from those of control cells ( Figure 4B).
body_text.section: PDE12 transgene expression alters the length of RNA poly(A) tails in mitochondria

body_text.text: These data indicate that PDE12 can degrade poly(A) tails in human mitochondria.
body_text.section: PDE12 transgene expression alters the length of RNA poly(A) tails in mitochondria

body_text.text: Removal of poly(A) tails by PDE12 has different effects on the stability of the various mitochondrial transcripts

Because there is currently no consensus as to the role of poly(A) tails in the regulation of mitochondrial transcript stability, we studied the effects of elevated mitochondrial PDE12 expression (deadenylase activity) on the steady-state levels of all 11 mt-mRNAs by northern blot analysis.
body_text.section: Removal of poly(A) tails by PDE12 has different effects on the stability of the various mitochondrial transcripts

body_text.text: Induction of expression of the PDE12 transgene resulted in a size reduction of mt-mRNAs consistent with the removal of the poly(A) from the mitochondrial transcripts ( Figure 4C).
body_text.section: Removal of poly(A) tails by PDE12 has different effects on the stability of the various mitochondrial transcripts

body_text.text: Deadenylation had transcript-specific effects on the stability of individual mt-RNAs.

Overexpression of the E351A mutant did not have any appreciable effect upon mitochondrial protein synthesis (Figure 6B).

Next, we carried out gradient sedimentation analyses of cell extracts from cells overexpressing PDE12 for 4 days and control cells in order to investigate the integrity of the mitochondrial ribosome (Figure 6C).
In this method, we detected the 28 S (small) and 39 S (large) subunits by western blotting of gradient fractions.
We used DAP3/MRPS29 as a marker for the 28 S ribosomal subunit and MRPL3 as a marker for the 39 S subunit.
The analyses of sedimentation of mitoribosomal subunits upon overexpression of PDE12 revealed:
(i) deficiency of assembled 28 S mitoribosomal subunits as compared to the control and
(ii) anomalous sedimentation of the 39 S subunits that was shifted towards slower migrating species (Figure 6C).
These changes in mitoribosomes were not due to any alteration in the length of the mitochondrial rRNAs, based on RNase protection assays of 12 S and 16 S rRNA (Supplementary Figure S4A-B).
Nor was the steady-state level or length of 7 mt-tRNAs (Ser-UCN, Leu-UUR, Thr, Gln, Pro, Lys and Phe) affected by elevated PDE12 expression (Supplementary Figure S4C-D).

However, in the case of tRNASer-AGY the steady-state level of the full-length molecule was $60% of the control value after 4 days of PDE12 overexpression and a species of lower molecular mass was detected.
A similar truncated form of tRNASer-AGY, albeit of much lower abundance, was observed in control cells (Supplementary Figure S4C).

Mutant tRNA levels considerably >50% are needed to produce a mitochondrial translation defect (24) and so the observed inhibition of mitochondrial translation is most likely attributable to the shortening of the mt-RNA poly(A) tails, owing to mitochondrial ribosome instability and/or impaired assembly.
Elevated levels of PDE12 compromise OXPHOS function
Mitochondrial ATP production and OXPHOS were analysed in cells-expressing PDE12, or the E351A mutant, to investigate the consequences of the increased deadenylase activity on mitochondrial function.
body_text.section: Elevated levels of PDE12 compromise OXPHOS function

body_text.text: Induction of PDE12, but not E351A, resulted in greater acidification of growth media (Supplementary Figure S3), suggesting that elevated expression of PDE12 results in increased dependence on glycolytic as oppose to mitochondrial ATP production.
body_text.section: Elevated levels of PDE12 compromise OXPHOS function

body_text.text: Furthermore, PDE12 transgene expressing cells had a reduced growth rate when cultured in medium containing 25 mM glucose (generation times: PDE12 = 1.42 ± 0.06, HEK293T = 1.27 ± 0.03 and E351A = 1.30 ± 0.03 days) and the growth impairment was accentuated when the cells' reliance on mitochondrial ATP production was increased by culturing them in medium containing galactose as the sole carbon source (generation times: PDE12 = 2.17 ± 0.13, HEK293T = 1.51 ± 0.04 and E351A = 1.48 ± 0.03 days) ( Figure 5A).

body_text.text: Finally, we analyzed steady-state levels of respiratory chain subunits, as OXPHOS dysfunction is usually associated with aberrant assembly or instability of mitochondrial respiratory complexes.

body_text.text: PDE12 overexpression for 4 or 6 days markedly reduced the abundance of components of complex I and subunits of complex IV ( Figure 5C).

body_text.text: The observed perturbations in the respiratory complexes in PDE12 overexpressing cells were additionally reflected by cellular oxygen consumption rates (OCR) that were reduced by $50% of the level of controls ( Figure 5D).
body_text.section: Elevated levels of PDE12 compromise OXPHOS function

body_text.text: The above results suggest that overexpression of PDE12 causes a severe defect in oxidative metabolism.

DISCUSSION
In this work, we show that the EEP family protein PDE12 is the human mitochondrial poly(A)-specific exoribonuclease.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Previously, it has been suggested that human polynucleotide phosphorylase (PNPase), which has a phosphorolytic 3 0 !
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: 5 0 exoribonuclease and a poly(A) polymerase activity, might be responsible for poly(A) removal in mitochondria (14).
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: However, hPNPase has been localized to the mitochondrial inter-membrane space, rather than the matrix where mt-RNA resides, and a role in processing of mitochondrial transcripts has been suggested, most likely by indirect means (15,25).
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: As there is no published data on the presence of other enzymes from the DEDD of EEP family in human mitochondria, therefore, PDE12 is the first recognized human mt-RNA deadenylase.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: PDE12 as a mitochondrial deadenylase

In the present study, we show that human PDE12 degrades poly(A) tails in vitro and that elevated expression of PDE12 results in shortening of poly(A) tails of certain mt-mRNAs in human cultured cells.
body_text.section: PDE12 as a mitochondrial deadenylase

body_text.text: The previous classification of PDE12 (2 0 -PDE) as an EEP-type deadenylase by Goldstrohm and Wickens (16) was circumstantial; PDE12 was reported to cleave phosphodiester bonds in short oligo(A) substrates when the 5 0 -phosphates of each adenosine are covalently linked between either the 2 0 -or 3 0 -hydroxyl positions (19).
body_text.section: PDE12 as a mitochondrial deadenylase

body_text.text: Until recently, the only suggested biological role of PDE12 has been the degradation of 2 0 -5 0 -linked oligo(A) in the RNase L innate immune response system and its cellular localization had not been studied (19).
body_text.section: PDE12 as a mitochondrial deadenylase

body_text.text: While our manuscript was in preparation, Poulsen et al. (22) reported the mitochondrial localization of PDE12 and confirmed that recombinant PDE12 produced in Escherichia coli is capable of degrading 3 0 -5 0 -linked RNA.
body_text.section: PDE12 as a mitochondrial deadenylase

body_text.text: Relatively short RNA substrates were used containing either
body_text.section: PDE12 as a mitochondrial deadenylase

body_text.text: (i) a 20-residue generic unstructured RNA sequence followed by 10 adenosine or cytosine residues or
body_text.section: PDE12 as a mitochondrial deadenylase

body_text.text: (ii) an RNA consisting of an 8 bp strong stem-loop structure followed by 10 adenosine residues.
body_text.section: PDE12 as a mitochondrial deadenylase

body_text.text: Longer incubation of the recombinant enzyme that lacked the predicted MTS with all three RNA substrates resulted in degradation into small fragments of 4-11 nt in size with comparable efficiency for all three substrates (22).
body_text.section: PDE12 as a mitochondrial deadenylase

body_text.text: In contrast, our studies of the biochemical properties of PDE12 isolated from human mitochondria show that PDE12 efficiently degrades poly(A) and poly(U), whereas poly(C) and poly(G) are not preferred substrates.
body_text.section: PDE12 as a mitochondrial deadenylase

body_text.text: Thus, PDE12 shares the same preference for poly(A) or poly(U) substrates as cytoplasmic deadenylases, such as PARN (26) and POP2 (27).
body_text.section: PDE12 as a mitochondrial deadenylase

body_text.text: Furthermore, we found that PDE12 isolated from mitochondria exhibits strong specificity to poly(A) when relatively long substrates containing a fragment of endogenous human mitochondrial sequence (over 100 nt of the 3 0 -end of ND1 or CO2) and poly(A) tails of 50 nt (close to the physiological length of the tails in mt-mRNAs) were used.
body_text.section: PDE12 as a mitochondrial deadenylase

body_text.text: The enzyme degraded maximally eight residues beyond the mRNA-poly(A) tail boundary.
body_text.section: PDE12 as a mitochondrial deadenylase

body_text.text: Eight nucleotides was also the maximum number of bases removed beyond the poly(A) tail of mt-mRNAs isolated from cells overexpressing PDE12.
body_text.section: PDE12 as a mitochondrial deadenylase

body_text.text: Therefore, human PDE12 has characteristics typical of a number of deadenylases: PARN, CCR4 and CAF1 (23,28).
body_text.section: PDE12 as a mitochondrial deadenylase

body_text.text: Moreover, as no RNA was truncated beyond the À8 position, PDE12 is not likely to be responsible for a general mt-RNA decay, as previously suggested (22).
body_text.section: PDE12 as a mitochondrial deadenylase

body_text.text: The discrepancy between the activity of PDE12 on RNA reported by Poulsen et al. (22) and in the current study could be owing to:
body_text.section: PDE12 as a mitochondrial deadenylase

body_text.text: (i) the molar ratio of the enzyme to RNA (100:1 and 1.7:1, respectively);
body_text.section: PDE12 as a mitochondrial deadenylase

body_text.text: (ii) the source of the purified enzyme (E. coli and human mitochondria, respectively); or
body_text.section: PDE12 as a mitochondrial deadenylase

body_text.text: (iii) the use of RNA substrates containing arbitrary rather then natural mitochondrial sequences (see above).
body_text.section: PDE12 as a mitochondrial deadenylase

body_text.text: The poly(U)-degrading property of PDE12 ( Figure 3B) could be of biological significance, as the presence of poly(U) tails in human mt-RNA has been reported recently (15,29,30).
body_text.section: PDE12 as a mitochondrial deadenylase

body_text.text: Interestingly, the polyuridinylated RNA identified in these cases contained unprocessed upstream or downstream tRNA genes in addition to a protein-coding region, and therefore might represent products of improper processing of the polycistronic precursor.
body_text.section: PDE12 as a mitochondrial deadenylase

body_text.text: This suggests that poly(U) tails play a role in the degradation of mt-RNA, and that PDE12 might contribute to this process.
body_text.section: PDE12 as a mitochondrial deadenylase

body_text.text: PDE12 has been suggested to play a role in 2 0 -5 0 -adenylate catabolism in the RNaseL innate immune response system.
body_text.section: PDE12 as a mitochondrial deadenylase

body_text.text: As all components of this pathway are localized in the cytosol, it is difficult to explain the previously postulated role of PDE12 in the context of its mitochondrial localization.
body_text.section: PDE12 as a mitochondrial deadenylase

body_text.text: It is possible, however, that an alternatively localized form of the enzyme exists, which is involved in the regulation of the RNaseL pathway, as suggested previously (22).
body_text.section: PDE12 as a mitochondrial deadenylase

body_text.text: Of note, degradation of both 2 0 -5 0 -and 3 0 -5 0 -linked oligoriboadenylates has been reported previously for other poly(A)-specific exoribonucleases (31,32) and might therefore represent a common property of this class of enzyme.
body_text.section: PDE12 as a mitochondrial deadenylase

body_text.text: Mitochondrial poly(A) tails and RNA stability
Polyadenylation plays an important role in regulating mRNA stability in many systems [see 'Introduction' section and ref. 7].
body_text.section: Mitochondrial poly(A) tails and RNA stability

body_text.text: The role of mitochondrial poly(A) tails in controlling the stability of mRNA has been debated.
body_text.section: Mitochondrial poly(A) tails and RNA stability

body_text.text: Different approaches have been undertaken to address this issue in human mitochondria:
body_text.section: Mitochondrial poly(A) tails and RNA stability

body_text.text: (i) prevention of the synthesis of mitochondrial poly(A) by depleting hmtPAP levels with siRNA (3,4,10) or
body_text.section: Mitochondrial poly(A) tails and RNA stability

body_text.text: (ii) trimming poly(A) tails by targeting the cytosolic poly(A)-specific nuclease PARN to mitochondria (12).
body_text.section: Mitochondrial poly(A) tails and RNA stability

body_text.text: Independent studies of hmtPAP gene silencing reached quite different conclusions as shortening of poly(A) tails did not affect the stability of the analysed mitochondrial transcripts (ND3, CO3 and ATP6/8) in one study (3), whereas others found that the abundance of several mitochondrial transcripts decreased in response to hmtPAP siRNA (4,10).
body_text.section: Mitochondrial poly(A) tails and RNA stability

body_text.text: It should be stressed, however, that siRNAinduced downregulation of hmtPAP might not have been complete and also the existence of a second polyadenylating enzyme has been postulated (33,34) that would additionally complicate the interpretation of the results of the downregulation of hmtPAP by siRNA.
body_text.section: Mitochondrial poly(A) tails and RNA stability

body_text.text: On the other hand, mitochondrial targeting of PARN completely removed the 3 0 -poly(A) extensions of mt-RNAs (12).
body_text.section: Mitochondrial poly(A) tails and RNA stability

body_text.text: This had a variable effect on mt-mRNA steady-state levels, increasing some (ND1, ND2 and ND5) and decreasing others (CO1, CO2 and ATP6/8), whilst still others were little changed (ND4/4 L and ND3).
body_text.section: Mitochondrial poly(A) tails and RNA stability

body_text.text: Deadenylation of mitochondrial transcripts as a result of overexpression of PDE12 had a very similar effect on the steady-state levels of the above transcripts ( Figure 4D).
body_text.section: Mitochondrial poly(A) tails and RNA stability

body_text.text: Thus, in both studies removing poly(A) tails from mt-mRNAs destabilized CO1 and CO2, whereas poly(A) addition promotes turnover of ND1 and ND2 mRNAs in human mitochondria, as previously proposed (15,33).
body_text.section: Mitochondrial poly(A) tails and RNA stability

body_text.text: Therefore, there is no universal role of mitochondrial poly(A) tails in regulation of the RNA stability, and two classes of poly(A) tails might exist in mitochondria that have opposite regulatory functions i.e. either stabilization or destabilization.
body_text.section: Mitochondrial poly(A) tails and RNA stability

body_text.text: If stable and degradation inducing poly(A) tails exist in mitochondria, how do animal mitochondria differentiate between them?
body_text.section: Mitochondrial poly(A) tails and RNA stability

body_text.text: Our data show that the efficiency of degrading of the poly(A) tails by PDE12 in vitro is different for certain transcripts, e.g. PDE12 deadenylates ND1 more efficiently than CO2 in vitro ( Figure 3C), and in cells ( Figure 4B).
body_text.section: Mitochondrial poly(A) tails and RNA stability

body_text.text: This might suggest the presence of RNA 3 0 -end cis-regulatory elements that modulate the deadenylating activity of PDE12.
body_text.section: Mitochondrial poly(A) tails and RNA stability

body_text.text: Perhaps, the structure of the 3 0 -end of the CO2 mRNA partially protects the transcript from deadenylation, which is particularly intriguing in light of the fact that the CO2 messenger becomes unstable upon removal of the poly(A) tail.
body_text.section: Mitochondrial poly(A) tails and RNA stability

body_text.text: In summary, our data confirm a previous suggestion (6,35) that polyadenylation itself is not sufficient to direct mt-RNA for degradation or to stabilise mitochondrial transcripts and that the regulation of RNA turnover must depend on additional, yet to be identified, factors.
body_text.section: Mitochondrial poly(A) tails and RNA stability

body_text.text: PDE12 as a regulator of mitochondrial translation
Our data show that PDE12 is important for regulating translation efficiency in human mitochondria.
body_text.section: PDE12 as a regulator of mitochondrial translation

body_text.text: The overexpression of PDE12 resulted in decreased translation rates for all mitochondrial proteins ( Figure 6) despite the fact that the steady-state levels of the majority of transcripts were not changed or were up-regulated ( Figure 4D).
body_text.section: PDE12 as a regulator of mitochondrial translation

body_text.text: There was an $50% reduction in the steady-state levels of only two transcripts-CO1 and CO2.
body_text.section: PDE12 as a regulator of mitochondrial translation

body_text.text: However, it is unlikely that the down-regulation of these individual transcripts could have caused the general inhibition of mitochondrial translation, as published data indicates that a comparable reduction in the steady-state levels of two or more human mitochondrial transcripts does not lead to a global translational defect affecting all mtDNA-encoded proteins (36).
body_text.section: PDE12 as a regulator of mitochondrial translation

body_text.text: The effect on mitochondrial protein synthesis is likely to result from the removal of poly(A) tails by the exoribonucleolytic activity of PDE12, rather then from a direct interaction of the enzyme with the mitochondrial translation machinery (e.g. ribosomes or translation factors) or from an indirect effect related to a defect in cell growth.
body_text.section: PDE12 as a regulator of mitochondrial translation

body_text.text: This is supported by the lack of co-sedimentation of PDE12 with mitoribosomes in sucrose gradient experiments or the lack of interaction with mitoribosomal proteins in pull-down experiments (data not shown).
body_text.section: PDE12 as a regulator of mitochondrial translation

body_text.text: Also, conditions that increase cells' reliance on mitochondrial ATP production exacerbated the observed growth phenotype ( Figure 5A).
body_text.section: PDE12 as a regulator of mitochondrial translation

body_text.text: No alterations were observed in the abundance of components of complex II (containing only nuclearly encoded and cytoplasmically translated subunits) nor other cytoplasmic proteins (b-actin or GAPDH) suggesting a specifically mitochondrial, rather than cytoplasmic, effect in cells overexpressing PDE12.
body_text.section: PDE12 as a regulator of mitochondrial translation

body_text.text: Here, again our findings are concordant with another study in which mt-mRNA poly(A) tails were removed by mitochondrial targeting of the cytosolic deadenylase PARN or coated by mitochondrially targeted human cytosolic poly(A)binding protein, PABPC1 (12), both of which resulted in marked inhibition of mitochondrial translation.
body_text.section: PDE12 as a regulator of mitochondrial translation

body_text.text: We excluded the possibility that mitochondrial translation is inhibited as a consequence of the partial degradation of mt-rRNAs by PDE12 causing instability or impeding the assembly of mitoribosomes.
body_text.section: PDE12 as a regulator of mitochondrial translation

body_text.text: This is in agreement with the observation that the 3 0 -termini of mt-rRNAs normally do not have >1-2 nt adenine nucleotides (3) and therefore might not present good substrates for PDE12 deadenylation.
body_text.section: PDE12 as a regulator of mitochondrial translation

body_text.text: Also, we did not observe a marked change in the steady-state levels of the majority of mt-tRNAs analysed.
body_text.section: PDE12 as a regulator of mitochondrial translation

body_text.text: Only tRNA-SerAGY-the unusual mt-tRNA, which does not fold into cloverleaf structure (37)-was downregulated by $40% and a shorter species was observed for this mt-tRNA.
body_text.section: PDE12 as a regulator of mitochondrial translation

body_text.text: This change is unlikely to account for the dramatic (almost 90%) translation inhibition observed after PDE12 overexpression.
body_text.section: PDE12 as a regulator of mitochondrial translation

body_text.text: As the truncated product of tRNASer-AGY was also observed in control cells, it might represent a relatively stable decay intermediate, which is more abundant in cells with inhibited mitochondrial translation, rather then a PDE12 degradation product.
body_text.section: PDE12 as a regulator of mitochondrial translation

body_text.text: Translation is principally controlled at the initiation stage (rather than elongation or termination), allowing for rapid, reversible and spatial regulation of cellular concentrations of proteins.
body_text.section: PDE12 as a regulator of mitochondrial translation

body_text.text: Nuclear-encoded eukaryotic transcripts are polyadenylated by the nuclear polyadenylation machinery.
body_text.section: PDE12 as a regulator of mitochondrial translation

body_text.text: Once the mRNA is transported to the cytoplasm, poly(A) not only stabilize RNA, but also promotes translation initiation.
body_text.section: PDE12 as a regulator of mitochondrial translation

body_text.text: Eukaryotic cytoplasmic initiation factors recognize the 5 0 -mRNA m 7 G cap structure and the 3 0 -poly(A) tail via poly(A)-binding protein leading to circularization of the mRNA, which is necessary for translation initiation (38).
body_text.section: PDE12 as a regulator of mitochondrial translation

body_text.text: The architecture of the mitochondrial translation initiation machinery resembles the one found in bacteria (8), and both bacterial and mitochondrial mt-mRNAs lack the 5 0 -end cap structure.
body_text.section: PDE12 as a regulator of mitochondrial translation

body_text.text: However, mature bacterial messengers do not contain poly(A) tails as polyadenylation consistently promotes mRNA degradation in prokaryotes.
body_text.section: PDE12 as a regulator of mitochondrial translation

body_text.text: If, by analogy to Eukaryota, mitochondrial poly(A) tails play a role in translation initiation their removal might primarily affect the stability of the 28 S small ribosomal subunit as this subunit binds mRNA prior to assembly of the 55 S mitoribosome (39).
body_text.section: PDE12 as a regulator of mitochondrial translation

body_text.text: This would be consistent with the results of our analysis of mitoribosomal sedimentation on isokinetic density gradients that shows the steady-state level of the 28 S subunit was notably lower in cells, in which mt-mRNAs were deadenylated by PDE12 overexpression.
body_text.section: PDE12 as a regulator of mitochondrial translation

body_text.text: The exonucleolytic activity of PDE12 can extend several nucleotides beyond the processing/polyadenylation site ( Figures 3C and 4B).
body_text.section: PDE12 as a regulator of mitochondrial translation

body_text.text: This observation brings about an alternative explanation of how polyadenylation could influence mitochondrial translation.
body_text.section: PDE12 as a regulator of mitochondrial translation

body_text.text: For 7 of 13 mitochondrial ORFs (ND1, ND2 ND3, ND4, CytB, CO3 and ATP6) removal of several terminal ribonucleotides (e.g. eight as seen for the ND1 mRNA) would result in truncation of a translation stop codon and at least two protein-coding triplets.
body_text.section: PDE12 as a regulator of mitochondrial translation

body_text.text: This might be sufficient to inhibit translation owing to mitoribosome stalling.
body_text.section: PDE12 as a regulator of mitochondrial translation

body_text.text: Studies of bacterial and eukaryotic systems have identified several mechanisms of regulatory stalling of ribosomes that inhibits protein synthesis (40,41).
body_text.section: PDE12 as a regulator of mitochondrial translation

body_text.text: However, the remaining six mitochondrial transcripts, ND4L, ND5, ND6, CO1, CO2 and ATP8, contain 3 0 -UTRs prior to poly(A) extension that are long enough to ensure the presence of an entire ORF, even after the removal of 8 nt.
body_text.section: PDE12 as a regulator of mitochondrial translation

body_text.text: Nonetheless, notably lowered steady-state levels of deadenylated mRNAs-encoding CO1, CO2 and ATP6/8 were observed in our experiments ( Figure 4C) and have been reported previously by others (4,10,12).
body_text.section: PDE12 as a regulator of mitochondrial translation

body_text.text: Therefore, the deadenylation-mediated inhibition of mitochondrial translation could depend on two simultaneous events: removal of the last 2-3 codons from the 3 0 -ends causing ribosome stalling and destabilization of mRNAs containing 3 0 -UTRs.
body_text.section: PDE12 as a regulator of mitochondrial translation

body_text.text: In summary, our study identifies PDE12 as an RNase that is directly involved in the regulation of mRNA poly(A) tail lengths in mitochondria.
body_text.section: PDE12 as a regulator of mitochondrial translation

body_text.text: Our results also underscore the importance of poly(A) tails in modulation of mitochondrial gene expression and suggest that in addition to being required for completing the termination codon of seven mitochondrial ORFs, they also play a role in mitochondrial protein synthesis.
body_text.section: PDE12 as a regulator of mitochondrial translation
